{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3154820,"name":"Ryan Elchahal","username":"Relch06","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-28T22:22:35.835Z","cooked":"

Hi all,

I hope all is well with you. I’m trying to implement a WPILIB PID Controller in order to control a Falcon 500. I was wondering what the “pid.calculate(encoder.getDistance(), setpoint)” function would output. Is there a certain range? We’re attempting to use a percent output control; would the PID Controller object work on the [-1,1] range which percent output uses?

Thanks in advance

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-02-28T22:22:35.835Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":207,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":1049.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":428473,"topic_slug":"pid-controller-wpilib-class","display_username":"Ryan Elchahal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pid-controller-wpilib-class/428473/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3154833,"name":null,"username":"phoenixPilot","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/97f17d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-28T22:44:12.266Z","cooked":"

WPIlib PID controllers don’t have a max range by default. The calculate method will return whatever value the controller calculates, regardless of size(e.g. kP = 0.1 & an error of 100, the controller will output 10). The result is in the same units that you tuned the controller in. As long as you don’t change what the input units are or what the output means, the units should stay consistent.

For keeping the outputs between [-1,1], you can use the MathUtils.clamp() method. (Its part of WPIlib)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-02-28T22:44:12.266Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":65,"readers_count":64,"score":48.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":428473,"topic_slug":"pid-controller-wpilib-class","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pid-controller-wpilib-class/428473/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3154838,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-28T22:50:26.241Z","cooked":"
phoenixPilot:

The result is in the same units that you tuned the controller in. As long as you don’t change what the input units are or what the output means, the units should stay consistent.

For example, if a position PD controller has position error (meters) as the input and voltage as the output, the P gain would have units of V/m and the D gain would have units of V/(m/s).
